item.title: Afghan Intelligence Says U.S. Drone Killed Taliban Leader in Pakistan
item.media:description: The wreckage of a vehicle that Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour was said to be traveling in near the Afghan border in the Pakistani province of Baluchistan on Saturday.
item.description: The statement, which has not been confirmed by the Pentagon, rejects Taliban claims that their leader, Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, was not in the area.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Arriving in Vietnam, Obama Aims to Lure It Away From China
item.description: Vietnam may grant U.S. warships access to its ports, and Washington seems certain to widen exceptions to its longtime arms embargo and may end it altogether.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: EgyptAir Was Aware of Threats to Security, Including One Scribbled on Plane
item.media:description: Relatives of an EgyptAir cabin crew member at her funeral service in Cairo on Saturday.
item.description: The airline had increased security in response to political turmoil, Islamist terrorism and “We will bring this plane down” once being written on the plane that crashed Thursday.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH, NOUR YOUSSEF and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Egypt Sends Submersible in Search for EgyptAir Jet’s Black Boxes
item.media:description: Prayers for the victims of EgyptAir Flight 804 at Al-Boutrossiya Church in Cairo on Sunday.
item.description: Egypt deployed a submersible to help find the wreckage of Flight 804, adding to an international flotilla of ships and surveillance planes scouring a section of the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Troubles in Rio for a Party Promising Brazil Salvation
item.media:description: Brazil’s new leader, Michel Temer, promised a new day of “national salvation,” but his party has a record of problems in Rio de Janeiro, where it wields great power.
item.description: The country’s new governing party has long wielded great power in this oil-rich state — a place afflicted by crime, graft, pollution and economic woes.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Mexican Officials Take Steps to Counter ‘the Trump Emergency’
item.media:description: Graffiti ridiculing Donald J. Trump on a section of the border fence separating the United States and Mexico outside Tijuana.
item.description: A number of influential Mexicans are worried about what a Trump victory could mean for the complex relationship between the United States and Mexico.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: How Kosovo Was Turned Into Fertile Ground for ISIS
item.media:description: After Friday prayers at the central mosque in Podujevo, Kosovo. The imam, a moderate, has tried to curb the influence of the fundamentalist ideology followed in the Persian Gulf.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Extremist clerics and secretive associations funded by Saudis and others have transformed a once-tolerant Muslim society into a font of extremism.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In Austrian Election, Far-Right Candidate Deadlocked With Rival
item.media:description: Alexander Van der Bellen, left, and Norbert Hofer, rivals in the presidential race, at a televised debate in Vienna on Sunday.
item.description: Norbert Hofer of the Freedom Party was in a virtual dead heat with Alexander Van der Bellen, a former Green Party leader, in the presidential election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: White House Letter: Obama Braces for Donald Trump Questions From World Leaders
item.media:description: President Obama at a briefing at the White House in early May, when he said that Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign should receive “genuine scrutiny” and that the race should not be treated like “a reality show.”
item.description: Private discussions at the Group of 7 summit meeting in Japan are likely to cover a topic not on the agenda: Mr. Trump’s chances of becoming president.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: John Kerry and Aung San Suu Kyi: A Milestone Meeting, Tempered by Questions
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and Secretary of State John Kerry at a news conference on Sunday in Naypyitaw, Myanmar.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nyein Chan Naing
item.description: Topics included Myanmar’s brutal treatment of a Muslim minority group and on the delicate question of whether Burmese military leaders once had a program in place to build a nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Greek Lawmakers Narrowly Approve Austerity Legislation
item.media:description: The Greek finance minister Euclid Tsakalotos, left, and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras at the debate in Parliament on Sunday.
item.description: The legislation includes higher taxes on coffee, alcohol, fuel and other goods and a mechanism to cut state spending if Greece misses its budget targets.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Party in Turkey Elects Binali Yildirim, Erdogan Ally, as Prime Minister
item.media:description: Binali Yildirim arrived at the Justice and Development Party congress in Ankara, Turkey, on Sunday. Mr. Yildirim, a longtime ally of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was unanimously elected prime minister.
item.description: Binali Yildirim replaces Ahmet Davutoglu, who abruptly stepped down this month after a public rift with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Gunman Fires Into Crowd at Concert in Austria, Killing 2
item.description: A gunman fired shots early Sunday into a small crowd attending an open air concert organized by a local motorcycle club, killing two people and wounding 11 others before shooting himself to death, police said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Arrives in Vietnam, Seeking to Turn an Old Foe Into a Partner
item.media:description: President Obama was greeted with flowers upon arriving in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Sunday.
item.description: President Obama arrived in Vietnam late Sunday to begin a three-day trip aimed at helping to counter China's growing assertiveness in the region.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Violence Flares in Afghanistan Among Various Groups
item.description: A conflict is beginning to look more like a messy civil war than a straightforward struggle between the government and the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: As Obama Heads to Vietnam, Current Events Overshadow History
item.media:description: Kieu Tri Huy, a Vietnamese photographer, with a poster promoting his Hanoi studio and featuring images of President Obama, who is visiting Vietnam.
item.description: With President Obama arriving on Monday, Washington and Hanoi have a chance to create a partnership that seemed unlikely even three years ago.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Migrant Crimes Add Volatile Element to Austria’s Election
item.media:description: The arms of an Austrian grandmother who was raped by an Afghan minor.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: Anti-immigrant sentiment is influencing a presidential vote on Sunday that could elect the first far-right head of state in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Thin on Influence, World Humanitarian Summit Will Tackle Aid Crisis
item.description: More than 170 countries — but few top leaders of global powers — will attend a gathering organized by the United Nations, the first of its kind, starting Monday in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Protests in Baghdad’s Green Zone Leave 4 Dead and 90 Injured
item.media:description: Men carry the coffin of a protester killed in a clash on Friday with the security forces guarding Baghdad’s Green Zone.
item.description: The United Nations warned that a sweep by security forces could hamper the fight against the Islamic State, while some termed the government’s response as excessive.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Decapitated Churches in China’s Christian Heartland
item.media:description: A cross that had been torn down by Chinese government workers at a Protestant church in the village of Taitou in Zhejiang Province last year.
item.description: A government campaign to remove Christianity’s most potent symbol from view has left the countryside in one region littered with chopped-off crosses.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Marco Pannella, Italian Champion of Civil Liberties, Dies at 86
item.media:description: Marco Pannella, left, in 1981. As the leader of Italy’s Radical Party, he championed the rights of women, gay people and inmates.
item.description: As the co-founder of Italy’s Radical Party, Mr. Pannella campaigned to legalize abortion, divorce and marijuana in his predominantly Catholic country.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: ‘Brexit,’ a Feel-Good Vote That Could Sink Britain’s Economy
item.media:description: The Brandauer factory was started 154 years ago as a maker of nibs for pens. These days, it makes components that are used in a range of everyday items, including cars and teakettles.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: In their desire to leave the E.U., many Britons have found an outlet for fears about immigration and terrorism. But the cost of an exit would be high.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: In China, Government Workers Push Rosy, Diverting Views Online
item.media:description: Men at an Internet bar in Beijing. China’s push to polish its image at home and abroad has gained new traction under President Xi Jinping.
item.description: A new study focuses on China’s “Fifty Cent Party,” who tout Beijing’s views online and make up a major part of its effort to control its image.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: U.S. Drone Strike Targets Taliban Leader
item.media:description: A photograph that was taken on a mobile phone is said to show Mullah Mansour, the leader of the Taliban.
item.description: The Pentagon said on Saturday that the United States military was still assessing whether the leader, Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, was killed in the strike.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: For This Green Smoothie, the First Ingredient Is Frog
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Hintau Aliaksei/Shutterstock
item.description: In Peru and Bolivia, drinks made from the endangered Titicaca water frog are promoted as a cure for many ailments, without scientific support.
item.dc:creator: EVAN GERSHKOVICH

item.title: What in the World: China Offers Airport Security for Women, and Their Makeup
item.description: “Female Only” security lines are at four airports, in part so women are not frisked by men, but also because cosmetics require greater scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: What in the World: A British Town Weighs Its Officials’ Merits, With Scales
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photos by Claudio Divizia/Shutterstock
item.description: Tradition equates getting fat in office with fiscal imprudence or worse, so once a year, politicians have to mount the scales in public.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Opinion: Among the Healers
item.media:description: Adalberto Salcedo, a shaman known as Delfin, near Guadalajara, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Daniel Borris for The New York Times
item.description: Therapy, medication and yoga couldn’t cure my anxiety. Maybe Rafael could.
item.dc:creator: DIANA SPECHLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Venezuela, God Does Not Provide
item.media:description: People waited in line in front of a state-run grocery store in Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, in January.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Amid deprivation and political crisis, Venezuelans have lost their ability to believe in anything.
item.dc:creator: EMILIANA DUARTE

item.title: Opinion: Israel’s Army Goes to War With Its Politicians
item.media:description: Gadi Eisenkot, right, with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during a swearing-in ceremony in Jerusalem in February.
item.description: The military and intelligence chiefs are trying to protect the state’s values from a dangerous right wing.
item.dc:creator: RONEN BERGMAN

item.title: Mao and Me: A Beijing Correspondent Reflects
item.media:description: Mao's portrait hangs in many cars in China, a talisman against accidents. This one hangs in the car of Chen Lei, a driver for a Russian bank. Taken in Beijing on May 18. 2016.
item.description: On the 50th anniversary of the Cultural Revolution, Didi Kirsten Tatlow knows she’s not the only person in China who’s dreaming about the Chairman.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
